extractedContent:
Application Number: 242845
Filename: BALDWIN FAMILY HEALTH CARE_Application-242845.pdf
Processed: 2026-01-22T22:56:58.696Z

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.evidence: In the application narrative, under '5. Describe how you will: a. Conduct and update your needs assessment', the applicant states: 'A needs assessment of the community is completed at least every three years. This assessment includes a thorough review of any changing patterns in factors associated with access to care and health care utilization, unique health care needs or characteristics that impact health status, chronic disease incidence and management, morbidity and mortality, and other needs that may be unique to service area communities.' The application also provides detailed data tables and analysis from 2022 and 2024, including UDS data, County Health Rankings (2024, 2025), and other sources. The narrative describes annual review of UDS data, board review of needs assessment, and use of patient and community input. The application includes recent data (2024, 2025) and describes a process for regular review and updating. The applicant also references review of hospital community health needs assessments and participation in community workgroups. The application narrative and data tables show the use of the most recently available data for the service area and special populations (e.g., veterans, homeless, persons with disabilities, youth at risk).
compliantItems.reasoning: The applicant provides clear evidence that a comprehensive needs assessment is completed at least every three years, using the most recent data available. The process includes annual review of UDS data, board involvement, and use of community and patient input. The narrative and data tables demonstrate that the needs assessment is current (using 2024 and 2025 data), covers all required populations and health indicators, and is used to inform and improve service delivery. The process described aligns with HRSA requirements for frequency, data sources, populations addressed, and use in planning. Therefore, the application is COMPLIANT with Element b - Update of Needs Assessment.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'The sliding fee discount program is designed to assure that BFHC patients have access to all services in the agency's scope of project, regardless of their ability to pay, while allowing BFHC to maximize revenue sources. The sliding fee discount program applies to all services provided within the federally approved scope of project for which there is an established charge, regardless of service type or mode of delivery. It is the policy of BFHC that no patient will be denied health services due to an individual's inability to pay for such services.' The policy was last reviewed and approved by the board in February 2025. The application also provides detailed definitions of income and family, methods for assessing eligibility, and policies for nominal charges and discounts. The policy is referenced as board-approved in both the narrative and Form 1C.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear evidence of a board-approved sliding fee discount policy that applies uniformly to all patients, addresses required areas (definitions, eligibility, nominal charges, discounts, etc.), and is current as of February 2025. The policy is referenced in both the narrative and compliance attachments, and is supported by board bylaws and Form 1C documentation.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 5A - Required Services Provided shows that all required services (e.g., General Primary Medical Care, Diagnostic Laboratory, Diagnostic Radiology, Preventive Dental, Pharmaceutical Services, Case Management, Eligibility Assistance, Health Education, Outreach, Transportation, Translation) are provided directly (Column I). Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule and Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance both include the sliding fee schedule, which is tiered (Slides A-D) and applies to all patients at or below 200% FPG, with nominal fees for those at or below 100% FPG. The application narrative confirms: 'For patients at or below 200% of poverty, BFHC offers a four-tier sliding fee schedule of nominal fees, which can vary depending on the service provided. Patients with income of 200% and greater of the federal poverty level are full pay.' The SFDS is consistent with the policy and is applied to all direct services.
compliantItems.reasoning: The evidence confirms that all Column I services are covered by the sliding fee discount schedule, which is structured and applied as described in the board-approved policy. The SFDS is detailed, current, and matches the requirements for discounts for all direct services. There is no indication of any direct service excluded from the SFDS.

compliantItems.element: Element e - Incorporation of Current Federal Poverty Guidelines
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule and Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance both provide the 2025 sliding fee schedule, which lists income thresholds for each family size and discount tier (Slides A-D) that match the 2025 Federal Poverty Guidelines (e.g., 100% FPG for a family of 1 is $15,650, for 2 is $21,150, etc.). The narrative states: 'The stated purpose of the agency's sliding fee discount policy, which was last reviewed and approved by the board in February 2025, is to ensure access to primary health care services for patients with no or limited insurance and whose annual individual or family incomes do not exceed 200% of the most current federal poverty guidelines published by the US Department of Health and Human Services.' The CFO is responsible for updating the schedule annually upon publication of new FPG.
compliantItems.reasoning: The sliding fee schedule uses the 2025 FPG, as required, and the process for annual update is described and implemented. The application provides both the schedule and a narrative confirming use of the most recent guidelines. There is no evidence of outdated FPG being used.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Documentation of Key Management Staff Positions
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff provides detailed job descriptions for each key management staff position, including responsibilities and minimum qualifications. Attachment 5: Biographical Sketches for Key Management Staff provides the training, education, and experience for each key management staff member. The application narrative (Capacity section) references these attachments and summarizes the qualifications and duties of the President/CEO, CFO, CMO, CDO, CHRO, Director of Operations and Compliance, Quality Director, Chief Security Officer/Privacy Officer, and Chief of Pharmacy.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application includes both position descriptions (duties/functions and qualifications) and biographical sketches (training and experience) for all key management staff. The information is detailed, specific, and covers all required positions. This meets the HRSA requirement for documentation of training, experience, and duties/functions for each key management staff position.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff (President/Chief Executive Officer) states the CEO is appointed by and reports directly to the board of directors, is responsible for planning, organizing, and directing overall activities, and has full authority to carry out administrative objectives. The bylaws (Attachment 2, Article VII, Section 7.1 and 7.2) state the board selects and employs the CEO, who is directly accountable to the board and responsible for administration of all facilities and departments. The organizational chart (Attachment 3) shows the CEO at the top, reporting to the board and overseeing all other key management staff. The staffing profile (Form 2) and narrative confirm the CEO is a direct hire (not contracted). The application narrative (Capacity section) further describes the CEO's oversight of the management team and day-to-day operations.
compliantItems.reasoning: The CEO is directly employed by the health center (not contracted), reports to the governing board (as documented in the bylaws, job description, and org chart), and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff and day-to-day operations. All required aspects of Element d are met and well documented.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements lists all contracts and referral agreements, including the type of agreement, description of services, and timeframes. The narrative in Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance describes oversight of contracts and confirms that the P/CEO and board review contracts for compliance with regulatory needs. The application narrative (Capacity section) states: 'The P/CEO reviews contracts for appropriateness and compliance with regulatory needs. Board members have been trained in FQHC rules and regulations and also review contracts for compliance before board approval. The corporate compliance program audit process also monitors compliance. A contract tickler system ensures that contracts are reviewed and renewed at appropriate intervals.'
compliantItems.reasoning: There is clear evidence that contracts supporting the HRSA-approved scope of project are in place, are reviewed for compliance, and are subject to board oversight and compliance audits. The contracts listed are for specific services (e.g., lab, radiology, language interpretation) and not for substantive programmatic work or subawards. The process described aligns with HRSA requirements for contract provisions.

notApplicableItems.element: Element e - HRSA Approval for Contracting Substantive Programmatic Work
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, question 2a: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: a) Contract(s) with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work within the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The application narrative (Capacity section) states: 'There are no subrecipients or contractors involved with the agency.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: This element is not applicable because the health center does not contract with another organization for substantive programmatic work (i.e., does not contract with a single entity for the majority of health care providers). All core and required services are provided directly by BFHC employees.

notApplicableItems.element: Element g - HRSA Approval to Subaward (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The application narrative (Capacity section) states: 'There are no subrecipients or contractors involved with the agency.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: This element is not applicable because the health center has not made any subawards. All services are provided directly or through contracts for ancillary/support services, not subawards.

notApplicableItems.element: Element h - Subaward Agreement (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The application narrative (Capacity section) states: 'There are no subrecipients or contractors involved with the agency.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: This element is not applicable because the health center has not made any subawards and does not have subaward agreements.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.evidence: The application narrative (Collaboration section) describes active collaboration with local hospitals (e.g., Corewell Health, Munson Healthcare), specialty providers (referral arrangements for ophthalmology, cardiology, etc.), and social service organizations (e.g., FiveCAP, Inc., District Health Department #10, Michigan Department of Health and Human Services). Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements lists ongoing contracts and referral arrangements with specialty and hospital providers. Letters of support in Attachment 9 are provided from hospitals, public health, mental health, schools, and social service agencies. The narrative details how RN care managers coordinate with hospitals for discharge planning and continuity of care, and how community health workers assist with social determinants of health.
compliantItems.reasoning: There is extensive documentation of formal and informal collaborative relationships with a wide range of providers and organizations in the service area. The health center provides specific examples of coordination with hospitals, specialty providers, and social service agencies, including written agreements and letters of support. The application describes processes for referral, care coordination, and integration of services, meeting the requirement for coordination and integration of activities.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Collaboration with Other Primary Care Providers
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.evidence: The application narrative (Collaboration section, question 2a) states that while there are no other FQHCs with a health center in a BFHC service area county, there are several in neighboring counties. The application lists these health centers (e.g., Cherry Health, Northwest Michigan Health Services, MidMichigan Community Health Services) and describes collaborative activities, including participation in the Michigan Primary Care Association, joint quality improvement initiatives, and letters of support from neighboring FQHCs (Attachment 9). The application also describes collaboration with state and local health departments, mental health agencies, and schools. Letters of support from Cherry Health, Northwest Michigan Health Services, and MidMichigan Community Health Services are included.
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center documents active efforts to coordinate and integrate activities with other federally-funded, state, and local health services delivery projects, including other FQHCs in adjacent areas. There is evidence of ongoing relationships, joint initiatives, and mutual support, as well as participation in the state PCA and HCCN. The application meets the minimum requirement to establish and maintain relationships with other health centers in the service area or region, and demonstrates broader collaboration with other primary care providers.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Participation in Insurance Programs
compliantItems.requirement: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.evidence: In Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, under Billing and Collections, the application states: 'BFHC contracts with all Medicaid and major commercial insurance companies operating in Michigan, generating third party reimbursements for eligible services and collecting client co-payments and self-payments.' Form 3 - Income Analysis shows projected income from Medicaid ($11,238,106.24), Medicare ($4,263,257.70), and Private ($16,509,617.88). The narrative also notes that the agency has a managed care and utilization review department and uses a certified EHR designed to meet all state and federal Medicaid regulations. Form 5A and Form 5B confirm that services are provided at FQHC-certified sites with Medicare billing numbers.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear, specific evidence that BFHC participates in Medicaid, Medicare, and major commercial insurance programs. The income analysis confirms actual and projected billing to these programs. The narrative and forms demonstrate operational systems for participation and compliance with these insurance programs. There is no evidence of exclusion from CHIP, and as Michigan's CHIP is administered through Medicaid managed care, participation in Medicaid generally covers CHIP. Therefore, the requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element h - Policies or Procedures for Waiving or Reducing Fees
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance and Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule provide the sliding fee discount policy, which states: 'It is the policy of BFHC that no patient will be denied health services due to an individual's inability to pay for such services.' The policy is board-approved (last reviewed and approved by the board in February 2025). The sliding fee discount schedule is detailed, with nominal fees for those at or below 100% FPG and discounts up to 200% FPG. The policy states: 'Patients are not required to apply for insurance and be turned down as a prerequisite for eligibility for the sliding fee discount; eligibility for discounts are based solely on income and household size under the HHS annual poverty guidelines.' The application further states: 'The NextGen electronic health record has fully integrated billing features and a comprehensive patient tracking system. It has the ability to flag accounts that are outstanding and automatically calculate co-pays, deductibles, and self-pay rates, based upon the current sliding fee scale and established federal poverty guidelines.' The board bylaws (Article IV, Section 4.1(d)) require the board to develop, adopt, and review financial management policies, including the sliding fee discount program and billing and collections.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides explicit evidence of board-approved policies and operating procedures for waiving or reducing fees, including the sliding fee discount schedule, eligibility criteria, and operational mechanisms for implementation. The policy is current, applies to all patients, and is supported by board bylaws. The procedures are described in detail, and the EHR system supports their application. The requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Budgeting for Scope of Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: The application includes a detailed SF-424A: Budget Information - Non-Construction Programs, a comprehensive Budget Narrative, and a Personnel Justification. The total budget is $54,502,344, which aligns with the projected patient volume and scope of services described in the application. The budget narrative explicitly states, 'The budget presented, along with the forms for staffing, income analysis and the SF-424, explains the details of each line item. These documents clearly identify revenue and expenses that are expected to be funded with HRSA grant dollars, Medicaid and Medicare reimbursement, and other sources of revenue. Program income is based on current state reimbursement rates for Medicaid and Medicare PPS for the state and expected reimbursement by payer.' The budget supports all sites and services listed in the approved scope of project (see Form 5A, 5B, and narrative).
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center has submitted a comprehensive annual budget to HRSA that reflects all projected costs and revenues necessary to support the full scope of project. The budget is consistent across all required documents (SF-424A, Budget Narrative, Personnel Justification) and aligns with the scope of services, patient projections, and sites. The narrative and forms demonstrate that the budget was developed specifically for the HRSA-approved scope of project.

compliantItems.requirement: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: The SF-424A and Budget Narrative both list all revenue sources: Federal (HRSA award: $5,173,516), State ($2,186,400), Local ($222,477), Other Federal ($16,863), Other Revenue ($13,895,798), and Program Income ($33,007,290). Form 3 - Income Analysis provides a detailed breakdown of projected income by payer (Medicaid, Medicare, Private, Self Pay) and other sources (state, local, grants, contributions, other). The budget narrative states, 'These documents clearly identify revenue and expenses that are expected to be funded with HRSA grant dollars, Medicaid and Medicare reimbursement, and other sources of revenue.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center's budget includes not only the HRSA award but also all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project. The inclusion of state, local, other federal, private grants/contracts, and program income demonstrates compliance with the requirement to account for all revenue sources supporting the scope of project.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Maintenance of Board Authority Over Health Center Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Section 4.1 states: 'Except as limited by statute, the corporation's Articles of Incorporation and these Bylaws, the board of directors shall have all the power and authority necessary to establish the mission, goals, objectives and services of the corporation. No third party(ies), including any other individual(s), entity(s) or committee(s) (including the Executive Committee), shall have approval or veto rights regarding any of the required power and authorities retained by a Health Center board of directors.' Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, Governance: Board Authority section, further references these sections and confirms that 'no other individual, entity, or committee...reserves approval authority or has veto power over the board with regard to the required authorities and functions.' Form 8 - Health Center Agreements confirms there is no parent, affiliate, subsidiary, or substantive programmatic contract that would infringe on board authority.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly articulate that the board retains all required authorities and that no other party can override or veto board decisions regarding the Health Center Program project. The application narrative and compliance attachment specifically cite these provisions, and Form 8 confirms no outside entity or agreement restricts board authority. There is no evidence of a co-applicant or public agency arrangement that would require further review. Therefore, the health center is compliant with the requirement that the board maintains authority over the Health Center Program project.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Required Authorities and Responsibilities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Section 4.1 lists the board's authorities and responsibilities, including: (a) hiring, annually evaluating, and dismissing the President/Chief Executive Officer; (b) developing, adopting, and reviewing personnel policies; (c) measuring and evaluating health center activities and performance; (d) developing, adopting, and reviewing financial management and accounting policies, including approval of the annual project budget and priorities; (e) developing, adopting, and updating health center policies, including scope and availability of services, location and hours, quality improvement/assurance; (f) ensuring policies are consistent with Health Center Program requirements; (g) approving applications related to the Health Center project; (h) engaging in long-term strategic planning; (i) evaluating itself for compliance; (j) monitoring financial status, selecting an auditor, and accepting the audit report; (k) assuring compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, Governance: Board Authority section, references these specific sections and details where each required authority is found in the bylaws.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws enumerate all required authorities and responsibilities as specified by HRSA, including those related to CEO selection/dismissal, budget approval, policy adoption, evaluation of performance, and compliance oversight. The application narrative and compliance attachment cross-reference these sections, confirming their presence and board control. No evidence suggests any required authority is missing or delegated inappropriately. Therefore, the health center is compliant with the requirement to outline all required authorities and responsibilities in its governing documents.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Sections 4.5 (Nominations), 4.7 (Vacancies), 4.8 (Removal), and 5.5 (Chairperson) specify the nomination, election, and removal process for board members and officers. Section 4.5(b) and 5.5 state that no other individuals, entities, or committees may select a majority of board members or the board chair. Section 4.8 details removal by vote of the board only.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly outline that only the board itself nominates, elects, and removes board members and officers, with explicit language prohibiting any outside entity or committee from selecting the majority of board members or the chair. This meets HRSA requirements for board autonomy in selection and removal.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Section 4.2 states: 'The directors shall consist of at least nine (9) but not more than thirteen (13) directors of which no less than fifty-one percent (51%) are users of the corporation's health care services as defined below in this section.' It further specifies representation requirements for non-user directors and limits on health care professionals among non-users. Section 4.2(b) requires user board members to be representative of the individuals served by the health center in terms of demographic factors such as race, income, ethnicity, and sex.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws explicitly require a board size within HRSA's range, a patient majority, demographic representativeness among user board members, and limits on health care professionals among non-users. All required composition elements are addressed.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 6A - Current Board Member Characteristics lists 9 board members, 5 of whom are health center patients (55.5%). The table shows representation in terms of area of expertise, patient status, and whether members live or work in the service area. The narrative in Attachment 13 confirms 51%+ patient majority, demographic representation, and that no non-patient board member earns >10% of income from the health care industry.
compliantItems.reasoning: The current board composition matches the requirements: board size (9), patient majority (5 of 9), demographic representativeness, and appropriate expertise among non-patient members. No member is an employee or immediate family of an employee.

notApplicableItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 6B - Request for Waiver of Board Member Requirements states: 'This form is not applicable to you, since you are currently receiving or applying to receive Community Health Center (CHC) funding and/or you have selected 'Tribal' or 'Urban Indian' as the Business Entity in Form 1A.' The application requests only 330(e) funding (see Summary Page and SF-424).
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The applicant is a 330(e) Community Health Center and is not requesting a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements. Therefore, this requirement is not applicable.
